title: Efficiently Learning the Accuracy of Labeling Sources for Selective Sampling

author: Pinar Donmez, Language Technologies Institute, Carnegie Mellon University

segmentation: Welcome everybody.

My name is Bernard en masse, and the title of my talk is efficiently learning the accuracy of labeling sources for selective sampling, and this is a joint work with Jaime Carbonell and Jeff Schneider from Carnegie Mellon University.
So let me first.
Briefly explain the problem that we are addressing in this work with an illustrative example.

Let's assume that for the simplicity we have a simple binary classification task where we have a small amount of labeled instances which are the colored circles in this figure and a large amount of unlabeled instances, and unlike traditional active learning frameworks, we assume that we have access to a bunch of a bunch of oracles or labelers annotators experts.
However, you want to call them, and we also we further assume that these oracles are noisy.
Meaning that they make labeling mistakes.
So they they might have different accuracy rates, but these are unknown to the learning algorithm.
So the question arises how?
How can you decide which oracles to query for the instances that you have?
If you have, you might have a limited budget that you may want your money wisely by selecting by selectively sampling the oracles.
So this is the problem that we are addressing.
In this paper.
And so let me just.
Recall our goal.

Our goal is to find the labels with the highest with very high expected accuracy, and we borrowed the idea from internal estimation learning, which is originally proposed by killing for reinforcement learning and we proceed as as follows.
The estimated reward for each labeler, and I will talk more about this on the next slide.
But let's just assume that we have a reward for each label for now.

And then we compute a confidence interval for for each label that we choose using this formula using the mean of the reverse under standard deviation that we have observed so far for that labeler, and then we select the labelers whose upper interval whose upper interval higher than some threshold.
So this way we can focus on only on the exam only on the label is that we believe have high accuracy and.

We can filter out the less reliable ones, and this will significantly reduce the labeling cost, and then for all the order for all the labels that we have selected, the Observare label that they output.
And then we repeat this process for a fixed amount of iterations or or depending on how much.
How much money did we have.
We can spend.

And the benefits of using a confidence interval like the formula shown in this slide, the benefit is that it automatically balances and exploration versus exploitation tradeoff, because the this interval can be high if the mean reward for that labor is high, which corresponds to exploitation, or it can be high due to the fact that it has large uncertainties in the reward estimates, and it is also.
A beneficial to sample that label, or in this case, because it means that we haven't sampled that label are enough to have a reliable estimate.
So this corresponds to exploration.

And then if we.
Keep doing that overtime.
The Oracles will shrink because we will.

We will have better estimates about the accuracy for those oracles, and the algorithm is going to become more biased towards the oracles that it thinks are the best ones, so it may end up selecting only one Oracle towards the end instead of selecting more oracles at the beginning.
